main_text:
We live in a world that seems to be brimming with causal activity. I
push the keys on my keyboard, and letters appear on the screen.
Outside the wind blows leaves across the patio. The ringing of the
phone cuts short my idling thoughts.

Philosophers have long wondered about the nature of causality. Are
there true causes at work in the world, and, if so, what makes them
the causes they are? How do causes bring things about, and what kind
of connection does a cause have to its effect? These questions took on
another level of complexity when various religious and theological
considerations were brought to bear on these issues. For instance,
philosophers came to question how divine causal activity is to be
understood, particularly, in relation to the natural causality of
creatures. It is from this context, in which questions about the
nature of causation intermixed with questions about the relation
between divine and natural causality, that occasionalism emerged.
Occasionalism attempts to address these questions by presenting as its
core intuition the claim that, regardless of our common sense
inclinations, God is the one and only true cause. In the words of the
most famous occasionalist of the Western philosophical tradition,
Nicolas Malebranche, “there is only one true cause because there
is only one true God; … the nature or power of each thing is
nothing but the will of God; … all natural causes are not
true causes but only occasional causes”
(OCM II, 312 / Search 448) A full-blown
occasionalist, like Malebranche, then, might be described as one who
subscribes to the following two tenets: (1) the positive thesis that
God is the only genuine cause; (2) the negative thesis that no
creaturely cause is a genuine cause but at most an occasional cause.
Not all philosophers who have been identified as occasionalists,
however, were full-blown occasionalists in this sense, since some
argued that only a limited subset of creatures lack causal powers, and
thus affirmed the causal efficacy of other creatures. For these
occasionalists, the two theses just stated above would be too strong,
and they would subscribe instead to a weaker position along the
following lines: while God is the unique genuine cause in some
restricted domain, other genuine creaturely causes are operative in
the world, and not all creaturely causes are merely occasional
causes.

Given this diversity of positions, it might be helpful to characterize
occasionalism as follows: one is an occasionalist for domain
x iff one holds that God is the unique genuine cause within
domain x and other alleged causes within this domain are not
real causes but at most occasional causes. And by “domain”
here, we refer to the roughly defined set of alleged causal relations
under consideration, for instance, the domain of causal relations that
hold between material or bodily substances. We will have more to say
about what an occasional cause is later on, but, at this point, on the
basis of the characterization of occasionalism just given, we might
introduce some terminology to refer to and differentiate the different
possible positions among those who subscribe to some form of
occasionalism. We will refer to the occasionalists who endorse the
full-blown version, along the lines of Malebranche, and take the
negative thesis that no creature cause is a genuine cause to apply
across the board to all finite substances as advocating “global
occasionalism.” Global occasionalism, accordingly, holds that
all creaturely causation is at most occasional, while divine causation
is uniquely genuine. In contrast, those who are willing to endorse
some genuine causation on the part of creatures, hence restricting
occasional causation to only a limited domain will be described as
endorsing a form of “local occasionalism.” (Lee 2008) 

Understood in this manner, occasionalism can be understood as a
metaphysics of causation that suggests a more discriminating attitude
toward what are typically taken to be causal interactions operative in
this world. On this characterization, the occasionalist resists a
univocal understanding of these apparent causal interactions and
identifies two types of relations in the world, that of genuine
causation and that of occasional causation. In addition to this issue
of the scope of occasionalism, we will, in the following sections,
examine how occasionalism addresses these issues aforementioned
concerning the relation between divine and natural causation, and what
arguments are presented in favor of occasionalism. We begin, however,
with a brief discussion about its history.
